;印度对大米运输实施更多限制，以确保其粮食安全最大出口国的关税可能会进一步挤压全球粮食供应。

;

;根据财政部周五晚间发布的通知，政府对蒸谷米征收 20% 的出口税，立即生效，证实了彭博新闻社早些时候的报道。印度现已限制所有非印度香米品种的海外销售，这些品种约占印度大米总出货量的 80%。它在全球大米贸易中所占份额约为 40%。

;

;本月早些时候，亚洲大米价格飙升至近 15 年来的最高水平，并且可能进一步攀升，导致菲律宾和一些国家等进口国的成本上升。非洲国家。

;

;印度最近采取的保护主义措施与其在明年初大选前冷却当地食品价格的积极努力相一致，届时总理纳伦德拉·莫迪将寻求第三个任期。

;

;“通过这一举措，国内价格将会下降，这将有助于政府控制食品通胀，”大米出口商协会主席 BV Krishna Rao 表示。 “但是，全球价格将会上涨，买家将不得不承受上涨的影响。买家和卖家之间还将就某些合同进行重新谈判。”

;

;大米是世界上约一半人口的主食。印度实施限制措施之际，由于俄罗斯在乌克兰的战争，以及全球不稳定的天气威胁着谷物和油籽的供应，食品成本仍然居高不下。人们担心印度确保国内粮食安全的举措将打击几个仍在努力从新冠病毒导致的经济衰退中复苏的较贫穷国家。

;

;新加坡敦促印度免除非巴斯马蒂大米出口禁令

;

;蒸谷米约占印度大米总出货量的三分之一。该国已经禁止出口碎米和非印度香米，限制小麦和糖的运输，并限制一些农作物的储存。印度还在考虑取消对小麦征收 40% 的进口税，并出售国家储备的西红柿、洋葱和谷物，以改善当地供应。

;

;预煮是一种在碾磨之前对稻谷进行部分煮沸的过程。提高其营养价值并改变米饭的质地。一些餐馆使用蒸谷米，因为它已经干净且易于烹饪。

;

;虽然对蒸谷米的关税于周五生效，但在政府命令之前持有有效信用证的出口商将被允许运输谷物，根据通知。

;小费文化似乎突然在韩国兴起，一些餐馆、咖啡馆甚至打车平台都会向顾客索要小费。

;

;鉴于韩国一直是一个无小费社会，许多人对小费文化的明显出现表现出了压倒性的负面反应.

;

;最近一篇题为“我们希望永远不要在韩国定居的外国文化”的在线帖子最近在网上疯传，其中展示了首尔一家受欢迎的面包店收银台上的一个玻璃罐的照片，里面装满了现金，上面贴着“ Tip Jar”英文。

;

;首尔面包店的 Instagram 账户上充斥着 200 多条负面评论，其中许多人要求店主删除它，称这种习俗荒谬且非法。

;

;该帖子促使其他韩国人分享类似的经历。一名用户称，首尔麻浦区一家咖啡店的一名员工要求她给小费，并展示了一款平板电脑，上面提供了高达账单 10% 的小费选项，而其他用户则表示，他们看到一些餐馆在桌子上贴了标牌，要求顾客给员工小费.

;

;小费文化甚至已经超越了咖啡馆和餐馆。

;

;占据国内网约车市场90%以上份额的Kakao T应用程序推出了小费试点

;

;在行程结束时，在司机将服务评价为五星级后，乘客可以选择向司机支付最多 2,000 韩元（1.5 美元）的小费。这是可选的，平台运营商兼 Kakao 子公司 Kakao Mobility 表示不会从小费中收取佣金。

;

;“我不明白为什么他们向我们索要小费，而我们却没有接受过任何值得小费的服务。与国外不同，顾客下单后自行取货，为什么要给小费呢？”一位 30 岁的郑姓顾客拿着小费箱在面包店排队等候了一个多小时，他告诉《韩国时报》。

;

;另一位姓金的顾客说：“在韩国，最终费用已经涵盖了服务人员，而且服务人员的工资至少达到了最低工资。

;

;“我讨厌其他国家的小费文化，在这些国家，服务人员的工资不够，而顾客则以‘善意’为借口承受负担。 '。我希望这种文化永远不会在韩国扎根。”她补充道，她怀疑小费箱里的钱是否​​会流向员工，而不是企业主。

;

;根据科技公司 SK 最近对 12,106 人进行的一项调查通讯方面，超过十分之七的韩国人认为给小费是“不可接受的”。只有 19% 的受访者表示给小费是个人选择，而 5% 的受访者表示支持。

;

;根据现行《食品卫生法》，韩国食品服务企业应在菜单上列出最终价格，其中包括税费和服务费，客户支付的费用不得超过此金额。

;

;为了应对日益增长的投诉，企业主正在退缩。

;

;截至周三下午，《韩国时报》观察到有争议的面包店的小费盒被从柜台上移走了。店主解释说，这“更多的是一种装饰”，增添异域风情，让游客感觉自己在旅行，没有顾客被迫给小费。

;

;同时，Kakao Mobility 表示，有超过 2,000 名乘客给了小费。他们的司机在推出该服务后的第一周内进行了测试，并相信这可以促使司机改善服务。例如，为孩子晕车而平稳驾驶或向乘客归还丢失物品的司机会得到小费。

;

;食品药品安全部周四向《韩国时报》证实，强迫顾客付费的行为所列指控违反《食品卫生法》的情况比所列指控还要多，地方政府定期对食品服务企业进行打击，以监督此类违规行为以及卫生和安全问题。

;

;中国的一则新闻报道，讲述了一对夫妇将行为不端的儿子绑在柱子上的故事他们吃饭时的美食广场引发了一场关于严厉育儿的新的公众辩论。

;

;这对来自中国东部浙江省的身份不明的夫妇被拍摄到惩罚他们的小儿子，因为他们在一家烧烤餐厅吃饭时跑来跑去并发出噪音。据月牛新闻报道，另一位张姓食客于8月19日拍摄了这段视频，视频中可以看到父亲用胶带将儿子绑在柱子上。

;

;这对夫妇随后用智能手机拍摄了儿子与录像带搏斗并试图挣脱的过程。

;

;张说，晚间高峰期间，美食广场挤满了人，其中许多人笑着说：拍摄了这个无助男孩的视频。

;

;张告诉月牛新闻：“我觉得这很有趣。”

;

;不过，该视频在大陆社交媒体上引起了不同的评论，抖音上的评论超过12000条。

;

;许多网上评论者批评这对夫妇的育儿方式。

;

;有人问：“有人报警了吗？”

;

;另一个人说：“我想知道这对他们的儿子造成了怎样的伤害。我觉得这一点都不好笑。”

;

;然而，有些人站在这对夫妇一边。

;

;“我也是一位年轻的父母。我支持他们的教养方式。”一位说道。

;

;另一位补充道：“儿子会吸取教训，以后会表现得端正。”

;

;关于严厉教养的故事经常成为人们关注的话题。

;

;6月，一位对儿子严格控制饮食的母亲因新闻媒体报道她强迫儿子吐出在同学生日聚会上吃的一块蛋糕而走红。< /p>;

;4月，中国东南部一名男子要求孙子向同学报仇，结果对另一名孩子进行人身攻击，引起公愤。

;

;去年年底，一名八岁的男子华中地区一岁男孩因看电视太多而被父母强迫看整夜电视的事件在网上引起热议。

;继日本排放福岛核废料引发争议之后，中国决定禁止日本水产品分析人士表示，周四的水可能会适得其反，并指出对中国自己的海鲜行业的潜在影响。

;

;他们表示，此举还进一步给两国本已恶化的双边贸易蒙上阴影，因为这表明他们如何尽管水产养殖在中日贸易中并不那么重要，但两国之间的依赖可能会减少。

;

;日本将福岛核电站处理后的核废水排放到太平洋的决定激怒了北京，导致立即封锁所有日本海鲜。

;

;“显然，北京对这项禁令的不满非常明显，即使目前还不知道或不知道该禁令对日本的影响。中国的一些反应似乎与他们对日本现有的怀疑有关，”新加坡国立大学政治学副教授 Chong Jia Ian 说。

;

;福岛的放水计划：视觉解释器

;

;他还指出，北京似乎并不承认废水排放已得到国际原子能机构的认证。

;

;“贸易关系，尤其是货物贸易，仍然很重要，但出于商业和风险管理原因，日本正在从中国市场转向多元化，尽管中国更注重国内生产和消费，”他表示。 “随着时间的推移，中国和日本对彼此的重要性可能会降低。”

;

;然而，中国禁止海鲜进口并不被视为对日本有深远影响的措施。

;

;“在目前，我不确定水产养殖在中日贸易中的突出地位。”庄说。 “如果北京方面认真反对，它可能会通过减少或限制从日本进口机械、电路和汽车来发出代价更高的信号。这将给日本带来更大的伤害，并给中国经济和消费者带来更大的损失。

;

;据报道，尽管中国是日本海鲜的最大目的地，但大多数水产品来自厄瓜多尔，其次是俄罗斯、越南和印度根据中国政府数据。

;

;根据海关数据，去年中日贸易总额下降 3.7%，至 3574 亿美元。 1-7月进口额同比下降12%，至1833亿美元。

;

;日本是中国第五大贸易伙伴，但考虑到其庞大的海产品进口总额，仅占其海鲜进口总额的一小部分。需求。

;

;中国业内人士担心废水排放和禁令对海鲜消费来说不是一个好兆头。

;

;尽管中国尚未采取任何行动来评估是否中国水产加工与营销联盟的一位工作人员表示，“从科学角度来看”废水是安全的，此举可能会对更广泛的海鲜消费造成打击。由于敏感，该工作人员拒绝透露姓名。

;

;“这肯定会对渔业和水产养殖业产生影响。”一些国内企业也会受到影响。”他说。 “据我所知……很多人不会吃海鲜，至少在短期内是这样。如果这种心态普遍存在，对于该行业来说是一个危险的信号。”

;

;位于上海西部苏州的咨询公司金砖四国农业信息技术公司预测，这将对中国的渔业和渔业产生深远的影响。水产养殖业，在周四的一份研究报告中。

;

;“公众对水产品的消费意愿可能会受到影响，沿海城市海鲜市场的客流量可能会下降，而此类产品的销量也会下降，同时价格也会下降

;

;香港日本人表示，尽管存在放射性排放，但该国的海鲜是安全的

;

;中国从 1 月至 1 月期间从日本接收了价值 19.37 亿元人民币（2.67 亿美元）的水产品7月，根据中国海关数据。由于对食品安全的担忧，7月份来自日本的出口额为2.35亿元人民币，环比下降三分之一。

;

;香港等地的消费者一直在囤积食盐。地方当局响应日本的决定，禁止从 10 个县进口水产品。该禁令涵盖活的、冷藏的、冷冻的、干制的和腌制的商品，以及海盐和海藻制品。

;

;山东大学海洋学院王亚民教授表示，废水可能会在一定程度上到达中国海域，但由于北太平洋的洋流方向，影响应该不大。

;

;“福岛附近的[循环洋流]顺时针方向移动，水流向东北方向，北美洲的方向走去。短期内不会有太大影响。”他说。

;韩国活动人士正在寻求阻止渔民出售鲸鱼肉的漏洞他们说，由于该国的鲸类兼捕数量仍然令人怀疑，因此被渔网意外捕获。

;

;今年早些时候，15 名立法者提出了一项新法案，标志着全面禁止消费鲸类的第一步活动人士表示，韩国是鲸类动物的国家。

;

;“韩国是世界上唯一一个通过法律保护鲸类动物，同时又允许食用鲸类动物肉的国家，”Jo Yak-gol保护主义组织 Hot Pink Dolphins 的负责人告诉《亚洲周刊》。

;

;韩国在加入国际捕鲸委员会暂停商业捕鲸后，于 1986 年禁止鲸鱼偷猎。

;

;'不可能”：日本会“放弃”印太捕鲸贸易协定吗？

;

;根据现行法律，如果鲸鱼不小心被活活捕获，渔民必须立即释放。如果发现鲸鱼死亡，他们必须迅速向海岸警卫队报告副渔获物，海岸警卫队将检查尸体以确保它没有鱼叉痕迹。如果检查显示没有此类标记，则会颁发许可证，使渔民能够将副渔获物作为公平游戏进行拍卖。

;

;以这种方式捕获鲸鱼在当地被称为“海上乐透” ，因为例如一头成年小须鲸的售价高达 2 亿韩元（15 万美元）。

;

;8 月 3 日，东南部城市浦项的检察官逮捕了五人，其中包括一名船长，检察官称，他们在今年一月至六月期间偷猎了九头小须鲸。

;

;为了掩盖证据，他们使用无法追踪的非法手机进行通讯，并在偷猎后立即在海上将鲸鱼拆解。拆解是指从鲸鱼身体的其他部位去除鲸肉。

;

;活动人士表示，偷猎和走私被认为可以弥补供需之间的缺口，因为通过兼捕提供的鲸肉并不能满足需求。足以满足需求。

;

;但是，韩国环境运动联合会 (KFEM) 领导人李勇基 (Lee Yong-ki) 表示，以合理兼捕为幌子非法捕鲸的现象同样严重，因为鲸鱼的数量这种意外捕获量明显高于其他国家。

;

;政府统计数据显示，仅去年一年就有 822 只鲸类（包括鲸鱼、鼠海豚和海豚）被报告为兼捕，尽管整体鲸类兼捕数量较 2014 年的 2,014 只有所下降。 2019 年到 2020 年为 1,350 头，到 2022 年为 1,066 头。

;

;“我们有严格的规则和制度，所有意外被渔网缠住的鲸鱼和海豚都必须立即向政府当局报告……这就是兼捕案件的原因一位不愿透露姓名的水产部官员告诉《亚洲周刊》。在此背景下，独立议员尹美香 (Yoon Mi-hyang) 和其他 14 名政界人士于 1 月份提出了一项修正案现行的海洋环境保护法，旨在禁止“故意兼捕”，并对违法者处以最高三年监禁或 3000 万韩元罚款。

;

;新修正案还要求海岸对网状鲸鱼进行警卫检查，而不是用肉眼进行粗略检查，但活动人士希望采取更严厉的措施，包括建立数据库，以防止渔民重复伪装成意外的非法兼捕。

;

;“我们欢迎这项修正案法案，但由于两大政党（朝鲜民主党和人民力量党）对此缺乏兴趣，并且担心渔民和鲸鱼肉餐馆的强烈反对，该法案在议会获得通过的可能性仍不明朗KFEM 的 Lee 表示。

;

;韩国东南部城市蔚山是韩国的工业中心，传统上被称为该地区的捕鲸中心之一，直到该国于 1986 年加入全球暂停捕鲸活动。

;

;鲸鱼尸体的拆除发生在南部长生浦港，地方当局现在寻求促进以鲸鱼和海豚为重点的旅游业，包括鲸鱼博物馆、拥有四只海豚的水族馆，以及在鲸鱼灭绝后的观鲸游船之旅。 1986年捕鲸禁令。

;

; Sat, 26 Aug 2023 14:20:02 +0800 Meta accused of endangering lives over Canada news block as wildfires ragehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3232394/meta-accused-endangering-lives-over-canada-news-block-wildfires-rage?utm_source=rss_feed

;Meta 被指控在加拿大关键时刻屏蔽新闻链接，危及生命35 岁的凯尔西·沃思 (Kelsey Worth) 是耶洛奈夫近 20,000 名居民之一，当时数千人逃离家园，迫切希望获得曾经在 Facebook 上广泛分享的山火最新消息。

;

;情况“很危险”。随着野火的蔓延，小镇上的数千人被命令撤离西北地区。

;

;她向法新社描述，对她自己和其他撤离者来说，找到有关整个地区大火的可核实信息是多么“极其困难”。近北极地区和加拿大其他地区。

;

;“没有人能够知道什么是真的，什么是假的，”她说。

;

;“当你处于紧急情况时，时间至关重要。”她解释说，到目前为止，许多加拿大人都依赖社交媒体获取新闻。

;

;Meta 于 8 月 1 日开始阻止在其 Facebook 和 Instagram 平台上分发新闻链接和文章。这是对最近一项要求数字巨头向出版商支付新闻内容费用的法律的回应。

;

;该公司一直在与渥太华就六月通过的法案进行虚拟摊牌，但该法案将于明年生效。

;

; >;

;该法案以澳大利亚推出的类似立法为基础，旨在支持陷入困境的加拿大新闻业，该行业在过去十年中广告费大量流失，数百家出版物被关闭。

;

;它要求公司像 Meta 和谷歌这样的公司，必须与加拿大新闻和信息媒体达成公平的商业交易——据提交给议会的报告估计，每年价值 3.3 亿加元（2.5 亿美元）——在他们的平台上共享，否则将面临有约束力的仲裁。

;

;但 Meta 表示该法案存在缺陷，并坚持要求新闻媒体在其 Facebook 和 Instagram 平台上分享内容以吸引读者，这对他们而不是硅谷公司有利。

;

;Canadian Prime贾斯汀·特鲁多部长本周对 Meta 进行了攻击，他告诉记者，“像 Facebook 这样的公司选择将企业利润置于[安全]之上……并让加拿大人了解野火等事情，这是不可思议的”。

;

;近 80加拿大所有在线广告收入的 % 归 Meta 和谷歌所有，后者对新法律表示了保留。

;

;远北地区 Cabin Radio 总监奥利·威廉姆斯 (Ollie Williams) 称 Meta 此举是为了阻止新闻分享“愚蠢而危险”。

;

;他在接受法新社采访时表示，“为了保护生命，Meta可以暂时解除禁令，并且不会受到经济处罚，因为立法尚未生效” ”。

;

;黄刀镇法语电台 Taiga 的 Nicolas Servel 指出，有些人已经找到了绕过 Meta 封锁的方法。

;

;他们“找到了其他方式来分享他说，例如对新闻文章进行屏幕截图并通过个人（而不是公司）社交媒体帐户分享。

;

;加拿大的几家大型报纸，例如《环球邮报》和《多伦多星报》，发起了活动，试图吸引读者直接访问他们的网站。

;

;但对于许多小型新闻媒体来说，随着社交媒体平台的根深蒂固，变通办法已被证明具有挑战性。

;

;特鲁多猛烈抨击 Meta 的封锁加拿大野火肆虐的消息

;

;公共广播公司 CBC 在本周的一封信中敦促 Meta 改变方向。

;

;“时间至关重要，”CBC 总裁凯瑟琳·泰特 (Catherine Tait) 写道。 “我敦促你们考虑采取急需的人道主义行动，并立即解除对处理这场野火紧急情况的社区的重要加拿大新闻和信息的禁令。”

;

;随着加拿大各地超过 1,000 场野火燃烧，她说，“对可靠、值得信赖和最新信息的需求实际上可能是生与死的区别。”

;

;Meta – 没有回应法新社的置评请求 – 拒绝了 CBC 的建议。相反，它敦促加拿大人使用 Facebook 上的“安全检查”功能，让其他人知道他们是否安全。

;

;蒙特利尔魁北克大学教授帕特里克·怀特 (Patrick White) 表示，Meta 已显示他说，“这是一个公共安全问题”。他补充说，他对渥太华最终将与 Meta 和其他数字巨头达成协议以解决他们的担忧保持乐观。 .

; Sat, 26 Aug 2023 12:50:02 +0800 ‘Return to paradise’, North Korea urged Japan’s Zainichi. Their reward? ‘So much pain and regret’https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3232333/return-paradise-north-korea-urged-japans-zainichi-their-reward-so-much-pain-and-regret?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.26 11:30;
;;

;Almost as soon as Hyangsu Park had arrived in the North Korean city of Wonsan, she could tell something was very wrong. It was supposed to be a routine visit with her mother to see her uncle's family – but her uncle was nowhere to be seen.

;

;Instead, there were only the distraught faces of her three cousins and their mother, Park's aunt, all sat in stunned silence.

;

;“My mum asked, 'Where's your daddy? Where's my brother?', but they said nothing,” Park recalls.

;

;Later – before Park and her mother had left Wonsan to return home to Kobe in central Japan, where Park grew up – her aunt quietly revealed that uncle Seok-geun Do had been taken away by the secret police. They had no idea where he was, but they knew he wasn't coming back.

;

;“They were very scared,” Park said. “我向他们保证我会回来。 “别担心，只要活着，活下去，我们很快就会回来，”我说。 But fate, and the North Korean state, had other plans.

;

;“I never heard from them after that. It's been 25 years,” said Park, 50, now a human rights advocate, speaking from her home in South Korea.

;

;Japanese mum, 86, loses hope of seeing daughter Pyongyang abducted in 1977

;

;In the years leading up to that fateful final visit, Park had grown close – through letters and phone calls – to the side of her family living in North Korea.

;

;And though the visits were rare, she had enjoyed seeing her cousins, aunt and uncle in that reclusive nation she'd been taught was a paradise on Earth, to play and share secrets about life in Japan.

;

;The mystery of what happened to them haunts Park to this day. Sadly, her story is far from unusual among ethnic North Koreans living in Japan: a community whose personal stories have been shaped by a dark history of colonialism, migration, war and discrimination.

;

;

;

;For decades now, Japan's North Korean community has been bound together by the Pyongyang-funded General Association of Korean Residents in Japan, or Chongryon.

;

;Over the years since its establishment in the 1950s, it has run everything from banks and restaurants to media companies and schools offering a Korean-language curriculum to appeal to Zainichi Koreans – the Japanese term for ethnic Koreans permanently living in the country who can trace their roots back to Japan's colonial rule over the Korean peninsula or earlier.

;

;“Suddenly there was this network of schools that attracted a lot of students,” said Tessa Morris-Suzuki, who studies Chongryon's role in the lives of the Zainichi community as an emeritus professor at the Australian National University.

;

;Why is anti-Korean racism in Japan on the rise again?

;

;“Many of them with parents who were pro-North Korean, but some who simply wanted to find a good Korean-language education for their children.”

;

;The schools offered more than just Korean language curriculums; they incorporated North Korean ideology into the lessons as well.

;

;“I went to a Korean school from kindergarten to high school,” Park said. “他们说我们的祖国是朝鲜。 I learned maybe this is the place I belong.”

;

;

;

;Between 1959 and 1984, 94,000 people – most of them ethnic Koreans – moved to North Korea from Japan.

;

;The exodus began with Chongryon heavily advertising what's been called the “return to paradise” programme, aimed at convincing Zainichi to abandon their lives in Japan for a fresh start in the so-called socialist workers' paradise of North Korea.

;

;Though it may seem absurd today, in the immediate aftermath of the Korean war, the North was seen for decades as the more prosperous and stable of the two Koreas – harnessing its rich natural resources to compete with and even outperform the South economically.

;

;“South Korea was a dictatorship for much of that period, too,” Morris-Suzuki said. “There was a sense that North Korea was developing its industry more rapidly, and had a more equitable social system.”

;

;In post-WWII Japan, meanwhile, the Zainichi were classified as foreigners and lived under a system that routinely barred them from the most stable careers.

;

;Japan colonised the Korean peninsula in 1910 and ruled it until its surrender at the end of World War II in 1945. By then, some 2 million ethnic Koreans were living in Japan. Most would later return to their now-independent homeland – but around 600,000 remained.

;

;Those who did, regardless of where they were born, were classified by the Japanese government as foreigners “residing in Japan” – the literal translation of Zainichi – as opposed to citizens.

;

;A “legal limbo” was the result, Morris-Suzuki said. “This meant that they were not eligible for a lot of areas of employment that require Japanese nationality.”

;

;Which made chasing the dream of a new life in North Korea all the more appealing for those, like Park's uncle Do, who decided to leave for “paradise”.

;

;

;

;The illusion soon began to crumble over the next 17 years, as Park's uncle – who she only knew from old photographs and her mother's stories – sent letters to Kobe pleading for financial help, giving the lie to the North's supposed prosperity she had been taught about in school.

;

;“My mum had so much pain and regret,” Park said. “我看到她哭得很厉害。每六名在日朝鲜人中就有一人将家人送往朝鲜。就像被扣为人质一样。我们必须忠于朝鲜政府，这样我们才能保护[我们的家人]。 We had to be obedient to Chongryon.”

;

;Then, on September 27, 1990, Park boarded a ship bound for North Korea. 17 岁时，她即将第一次亲眼目睹这片她曾多次听说但从未见过的土地。 Accompanying her on the two-week trip was her mother, eager to spend some time with a man she hadn't seen since he was a teenager: Park's uncle Do.

;

;Photos of her taken at the time in a traditional blue-and-white hanbok adorned with a small pin of a beaming Kim Il-sung still bring a smile to Park's face. She recalls scanning the crowd gathered at the port of Wonsan to welcome the ship as it arrived and instantly spotting her cousins thanks to the clothes that they wore, sent from Japan.

;

;“It was so strange, it was the first time in my life I saw my cousins, but they looked very similar to me,” she said. “I can't forget that.”

;

;Park's memories of her second visit, six years later, are far less pleasurable.

;

;It was 1996 or early 1997 and the Soviet Union, one of Pyongyang's most important benefactors, had collapsed leaving the North Korean economy in tatters.正如国家宣传所描述的1994-98年期间，在“艰难的行军”期间，由于洪水、干旱和经济管理不善，饥荒席卷了朝鲜。 Some half a million people starved to death, according to US estimates, though the true total may never be known.

;

;Against this backdrop, Park again arrived in Wonsan – only to find the side of her family who were living in North Korea missing her uncle Do.

;

;Her mother, desperate to learn what had happened to her brother, managed to secure some private time with the family through by paying a bribe.

;

;“We gave so much money to that watchman and the final day they allowed us to visit their house, maybe three or four hours before we left,” Park said.

;

;“When we arrived, they all started to cry.他们受到威胁。他们告诉我他们也可能被捕。 They were shaking.”

;

;

;

;More than a decade later, Park would learn that her uncle had been arrested and tortured to death, and her aunt and cousins sent to the notorious Yodok concentration camp for political prisoners soon after her departure – never to be heard from again.

;

;Their crime? Being on an international phone call during which someone wished for the end of the Kim regime.

;

;Today, the “return to paradise” programme is more commonly thought of as a forced migration scheme. The UN Human Rights Office's Working Group on Enforced or Involuntary Disappearances has now heard the testimony of Park and more than 100 others alleging such abuses by the North Korean government, according to Lee Ji-yoon of the Seoul-based Citizens' Alliance for North Korean Human Rights, which helped them submit their evidence.

;

;Japan's Kishida says willing to meet North Korea's Kim Jong-un over kidnappings

;

;But while Pyongyang was almost certainly the scheme's architect, some believe the Japanese government shares culpability. Recently declassified documents Morris-Suzuki has studied reveal Tokyo officials and the Japanese Red Cross Society discussing ways to convince Zainichi to leave Japan years before “return to paradise” was first announced.

;

;Park, who now works with the defector community in South Korea to raise awareness, said human rights abuses were the norm in the North.

;

;“This is the reality of North Korea,” she said. “It's not only the story of my family, so many similar stories are happening in North Korea.”

;MSA Capital manages US dollar funds with capital from sovereign wealth funds, international asset managers and pension funds, as well as Chinese entrepreneurs.

;With more investors like MSA Capital trying to dodge the sanctions bullet, the backers of these funds will also have to rethink their China strategies given rising geopolitical acrimony.

;Jiang added that the biggest disruption from new investment restrictions will be the deterrence factor for potential investors in China.

;

;While US dollar limited partners (LPs) – the investors who back venture funds without being involved in day-to-day management – come from all over the world, including America, the Middle East and Southeast Asia, “historically LPs from the US account for the most significant share of all types of dollar LPs,” said Jiang. “The investment restrictions will make the LPs have second thoughts about allocating any money to China.”

;

;In August, the Biden administration unveiled an executive order aimed at restricting US venture capital and private equity investments in Chinese companies involved in semiconductors, microelectronics, quantum technologies and AI systems.

;

;Washington's move to screen outbound investments came as American venture capital money was already drying up in the Chinese market, according to analysts at independent market research firm Rhodium Group. Its data shows that US backing of China start-ups plunged to a 10-year-low last year to US$1.27 billion, well down from a peak of US$14.4 billion in 2018.

;

;While the tougher restrictions were largely anticipated by the global investment community, practitioners said that the announcement has been the final nail in the coffin for investment in the sanctioned sectors.

;

;Tighter US chip export controls on China will mean 'permanent' loss: Nvidia

;

;Kaidi Gao, an analyst at investment data service Pitchbook, said some of the largest LPs – such as pension funds on the private equity side – have now pulled back completely from fresh investment in China.

;

;A recent report by investment research firm Preqin showed that China-focused VC funds raised US$2.7 billion from April to June, a plunge of 54.2 per cent from the previous quarter. Meanwhile, for sectors like semiconductors, funding has long been migrating to local yuan funds, according to local industry experts.

;

;The Chinese founder of a memory controller chip design firm, who asked not to be identified due to the sensitivity of the matter, told the Post on his return from a fundraising trip, that many small Chinese chip start-ups aim to supply state-backed companies when their products are ready or they go public on the mainland's tech-heavy STAR market. In this situation, “taking US money would send a bad signal in either case”, he said.

;

;That comment echoes remarks made at the 2023 China Semiconductor Equipment Annual Conference (CSEAC) earlier this month, where an investor from venture capital fund Fountain Bridge Capital said they have long separated US funds and yuan funds for investment targets in China's semiconductor industry, with the latter the only way to currently invest in the sector.

;

;The semiconductor sector has always been a special case, with long investment horizons and high risks due to its asset-heavy profile.

;

;The sector used to be shunned by private money until China's self-sufficiency drive intensified due to increased tensions with Washington. Many Chinese private equity and venture capital funds were seen chasing executives at CSEAC to talk about investment opportunities.

;

;To date the state-backed China Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund, also known as the Big Fund, has been the main vehicle for the Chinese government to pump money into the chip sector. The first phase of the fund raised US$19.7 billion with the second raising about US$30 billion, and it has made multiple bets on Chinese semiconductor companies since its creation in September 2014.

;

;It is difficult to estimate the overall subsidy package extended by Beijing and local governments to the domestic chip industry, as many forms of grants are not necessarily handed out in cash terms.

;

;Softbank-backed Arm warns of 'significant' China risk in its IPO prospectus

;

;The memory controller chip founder said the city government of Zhengzhou, capital of central Henan province, wants to have skin in the game by providing cheap land parcels, factory facilities and even by paying for some equipment rather than through direct investments, as some of their financial vehicles have been damaged by China's patchy economy.

;

;However, for some industry practitioners, local yuan funding can never make up for the loss of US dollar funds, which typically have a long investment maturity and high-risk tolerance.

;

;One Shanghai-based investor, who also requested anonymity due to the sensitivity of the topic, said a strength of US dollar funds is their ability to back high-risk projects, setting them apart from many yuan funds that take money from so-called government guidance funds, which are typically more risk averse. Local currency funds are less likely to invest in early projects with no income, added the investor.

;

;In a recent round-table discussion, Duane Kuang Ziping, founding and managing partner at China-based Qiming Venture Partners, said US dollar funds have a preference for risky projects that have the potential to generate outsized returns.

;

;“Using graphics processing units (GPU) as an example, RMB funds would not bet on GPU projects until the world's first GPU start-up has been validated [for its potential],” Kuang said in dialogue with Yang Xiaolei, CEO at local investment intelligence service China Venture, according to an article published by the firm.

;

;Kuang also said that despite the current ChatGPT frenzy in China – which has seen local firms rush to compete with OpenAI's breakthrough generative AI product, RMB funds would never have backed a research lab like OpenAI in the first place. This is because yuan funds will not take a risk if the development pattern and growth path are not already clear, he said.

;

;With tougher US investment restrictions now in place, this poses a particular problem for those Chinese start-ups looking to replicate or exceed OpenAI's success with its ChatGPT chatbot, which can provide human-like responses to user questions.

;

;The Shanghai-based investor said although the hype surrounding China's generative AI sector is still gathering steam, there are fundamental obstacles to turning a potential ChatGPT competitor into a profitable business.

;

;China to make steady progress in chip equipment self-sufficiency: UBS

;

;The last batch of Chinese AI giants, such as SenseTime and Megvii, had a sizeable share of revenue coming from government orders or subsidies. But the Chinese government has not shown an equal amount of love for the generative AI sector, which will also be subject to the country's strict online censorship regime.

;

;To date, all domestically-developed AI chat bots are still in the public testing phase, and no company has yet been given the green light to roll out their products to the public on a commercial basis.

;

;On the business side, companies have been beta-testing their AI bots in traditional industries to improve efficiency and lower costs. But the financial case has yet to be proven.

;

;iFlyTek, a Chinese AI firm that said it had surpassed the capacity of OpenAI's ChatGPT in October, saw its net income fall 74 per cent in the first half from a year earlier. The revenue plunge came months after the Anhui, Hefei-based company launched its ChatGPT-like bot SparkDesk in early May, trumpeting its integration into a wide range of traditional industries.

;

;Baidu, which unveiled its Ernie Bot earlier this year, had a strong second quarter with revenue growth of 15 per cent, but financial details related to its generative AI efforts are scant.

;

;Co-founder, chairman and CEO Robin Li Yanhong said in the earnings call that generative AI “holds immense transformative power in numerous industries, presenting a significant market opportunity” for the company, without disclosing how much revenue it has made from the service.

;

;Despite the hazy financials, generative AI remains a hot sector for investors.

;

;“The AI leaders are mainly in China and the US … where the technologies are mostly being created and the leading companies are going to be,” said Jeffrey Towson, a partner at research firm TechMoat Consulting. “世界上有很多资本。 But only two big epicentres for AI.”

;

;But as the geopolitical storm continues to gather for US investors in China, it seems increasingly likely that they will steer clear.

;

;Long-time SMIC investor Walden International has watched as the foundry delisted from the New York Stock Exchange in 2019 after 15 years of trading and floated its shares in Shanghai the following year.

;

;The Big Fund and local firms such as Datang Telecom Technology as well as China Information and Communication Technology Group among other state-affiliated firms, have since emerged as some of SMIC's biggest backers, according to the company's latest annual report.

;

;Meanwhile, the San Francisco-based firm has just received a letter from the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party expressing “serious concern” and probing its investments in Chinese tech start-ups.
